stream_context.summary: Kaze focused on designing and greyboxing the 'Snowman Cave' level. He brainstormed ideas for different rooms, built out a multi-pathed cliff climbing section, and refined his plans for the level's overall flow. He also tweaked a camera shake effect for an elevator and discussed his future YouTube content strategy and the impending birth of his daughter.

development_findings.summary: Kaze's level design process involves 'greyboxing'—creating the level with simple geometry to finalize platforming gameplay and flow before adding final art assets.
development_findings.quote: I call it the case method because I just made it up.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is planning to rework the game's shadow rendering by making shadows a separate object from the player character, allowing them to correctly project onto floors different from the one Mario is standing on.
development_findings.quote: My idea for the shadows is that it's actually going to be a whole separate object, separate from Mario... That way it will be all fine. So it can have a different floor from Mario.

development_findings.summary: Kaze plans to release a public demo for Course 1 and use a Google document to gather detailed community feedback on physics and camera to fine-tune the game feel.
development_findings.quote: I'm gonna have like a Google document where people can answer all kinds of questions... to get as much feedback as possible. So I can make minuscule adjustments and get the physics feeling just right.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is considering creating an open-source project after RTYI is complete to port all of his engine optimizations back into the original SM64 decompilation for other modders to use.
development_findings.quote: I'll likely start like an open source project to do that. And then everyone can contribute to that. The idea would be to port back all of the RTUI optimizations to vanilla Mark 64.

development_findings.summary: Kaze's design brainstorming for the snowman cave led him to identify key tropes for the level theme, including a slide section, a cliff-climbing section, a void platforming room, and a final treasure room.
development_findings.quote: We can't have an ice cave without a slight.

development_findings.summary: When faced with a visually unappealing section, Kaze prioritizes perfecting the platforming mechanics and layout before addressing the aesthetics, which he'll fix later.
development_findings.quote: Wow, that is ugly. Oh my God... I like the platforming aspects of this, just not the way it looks.

development_findings.summary: Kaze has developed a highly efficient workflow for testing builds directly on original N64 hardware using an Everdrive flash cart.
development_findings.quote: Look how fast N64 testing is now that I have to set up. I just click the bat and it's there, it's right on my N64.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is committed to developing the game within the original N64's 64MB cartridge size limitation, viewing it as a core part of the challenge and a way to avoid criticism.
context_findings.quote: If I don't stay within the original limitations, am I not kind of cheating? You see the issue. I don't want to finish the game and then people are like, oh, yeah, but you used more memory, though.

context_findings.summary: Kaze states that Nintendo dislikes him for making Mario mods and has taken down 70 of his YouTube videos as evidence of their animosity.
context_findings.quote: They took down 70 of my videos, just so you are aware of how much they hate me.

context_findings.summary: Kaze reflects on a four-year period of extreme isolation and poverty in his past, which he says made him 'go a bit crazy' but also taught him to appreciate small sensory experiences.
context_findings.quote: For like four years I just lived like by myself alone without ever talking to anyone and that does make you go a bit crazy... I stood there and was like, man, this is nice. I like just smelling the sausage. You just start appreciating like the smallest things.

context_findings.summary: Kaze and his wife, Zeina, are expecting their first child, a daughter to be named Reyna, in five days. This may impact his ability to stream next week.
Kaze is investing in his YouTube presence by hiring a video editor and believes he has enough content ideas to significantly grow his channel to one million subscribers.
context_findings.quote: I have now have someone who wants to edit my videos. I pay him, I think like $16 per minute of video... I feel like we could hit a million subs if we actually went in hard on that.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses his disdain for Unity's recent policy changes and states that if he were to make an original commercial game, he would use Unreal Engine.
context_findings.quote: Unity kind of fucked itself over with its stupid rules now. So that I don't want to use it anymore... If I was going to make a game, it would be an Unreal Engine.

biobak.summary: Kaze explained that Biobak's role includes polishing and improving the 3D models after Kaze creates the initial versions.
biobak.quote: He whenever I'm done with the model, he looks over it again and makes it look a lot better.

biobak.summary: Biobak provided a status update in chat, indicating he is working on in-game text and making progress on Course 11.
biobak.quote: I added all the texts for all the acts to the workers yesterday. Getting so much work done on cross 11.

badub.summary: Kaze confirmed that Badub is the composer for the project.

zeina.summary: Kaze stated that Zeina contributes concept art and is responsible for the project's animations.
zeina.quote: We got Zayna helping with a lot of stuff. Mostly like concept art and stuff... Oh yeah, animations are the biggest one she's doing.

zeina.summary: Kaze's wife, Zeina, is expecting their daughter in five days, highlighting a significant life event happening alongside the project's development.

key_stories.title: Tuning the Elevator Shake
key_stories.summary: Kaze noticed an elevator's camera shake was jarring and looked like a bug. He systematically disabled parts of the effect and tuned its parameters until it created a subtle, atmospheric feel, demonstrating his iterative polish process.
key_stories.challenge: A visual effect for an elevator was too intense, with a camera shake that was 'way too much' and an FOV shake that made the game look like it was bugged.
key_stories.process: Kaze iteratively tweaked the code parameters for the shake effect, playtested the result, identified the specific component that looked wrong (FOV shake), and searched for a new sound effect.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze refined the effect by removing the FOV shake, reducing the shake's magnitude, and adding a fitting sound, resulting in a subtle, atmospheric effect he was happy with.
key_stories.key_quote: The FOV shake kind of makes this look like a bugged camera, doesn't it?

key_stories.title: The Ugly Cliff Climb
key_stories.summary: While greyboxing a cliff-climbing area, Kaze found the visuals ugly but decided to focus entirely on the platforming. Through playtesting and iterative geometric tweaks, he perfected the gameplay flow, embodying his 'gameplay first' design philosophy.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze designed a cliff-climbing section that he felt was functional but visually 'truly, truly disgusting'.
key_stories.process: Instead of getting stuck on the poor visuals, Kaze focused on the gameplay. He playtested the section, identified points of frustration (getting stuck, tight jumps), and adjusted the greybox geometry to improve the flow and create multiple paths.
key_stories.outcome: He successfully refined the gameplay of the section by making small adjustments to the geometry, ensuring it was fun to traverse. The visual overhaul was deferred for a later stage.
key_stories.key_quote: I like the platforming aspects of this, just not the way it looks.

key_stories.title: Nintendo's 70 Takedowns
key_stories.summary: When asked about Nintendo, Kaze explained his adversarial relationship with the company. He stated they 'hate' him for his work and revealed that they have successfully taken down 70 of his videos, providing a stark example of the risks he faces.
key_stories.challenge: A chatter in the stream questioned why Nintendo would take action against Kaze's projects.
key_stories.process: Kaze bluntly stated that Nintendo 'fucking hate me' for creating Mario mods. He then provided a concrete number—70—of his videos that the company has had taken down from YouTube to illustrate his point.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze established the serious and quantified nature of his conflict with Nintendo, framing it as a significant external pressure on his work.
key_stories.key_quote: They took down 70 of my videos, just so you are aware of how much they hate me.

open_questions.context: Kaze explained that Biobak polishes his 3D models and Zeina provides concept art and animation. However, the specific step-by-step workflow and feedback loop between the three is unclear.
questions: Can you walk us through the typical lifecycle of an asset, from Zeina's concept art to your initial model to Biobak's final polish?
How does the feedback process work between the core team? Can you give an example of a time Biobak's or Zeina's input significantly changed your initial plan for a character or level piece?
How are Zeina's animations integrated into the game? Does she work with rigs you've created, and how do you handle that technical handoff?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned he might start an open-source project to port his RTYI engine optimizations back to the vanilla SM64 decompilation for other modders to use.
questions: What is your main motivation for wanting to release your engine optimizations as an open-source project?
What do you hope the SM64 modding community will be able to achieve with these improved tools?
Which of your optimizations do you consider the most significant or impactful for other developers?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned a period of about four years where he was extremely isolated and lived on very little money. He said it made him 'go a bit crazy' but also taught him to appreciate small things.
questions: You described a four-year period of intense isolation. How do you feel that experience has shaped you as a person and as a game developer?
Does that philosophy of appreciating 'the smallest things,' like the smell of sausage you mentioned, influence your design principles today?
You also mentioned having a powerful false memory from that time. Could you elaborate on how that experience of your mind playing tricks on you has affected your perspective?

open_questions.context: Kaze briefly explained a plan to fix shadows by making them a separate object that detects the floor independently from Mario. When asked for more detail, he dismissed the question.
questions: You mentioned a plan to rework the shadow system to be a separate object. Could you explain in more detail the technical challenges that led to this decision?
What specific visual or gameplay problems will this new shadow system solve that the original engine couldn't handle?
